segments.advisor_message: So, in our discussions, I mentioned the concept of tax residency, which basically refers to whether you're considered a tax resident in the country you live in. Do you understand how tax residency affects your financial planning?
segments.client_message: I think I get it, but can you explain that tax residency thing a bit more? It sounds important but I'm not sure how it works, you know?

segments.advisor_message: Absolutely! Being a tax resident means you're liable to pay taxes in that country on your worldwide income. For example, if you're living and working in the UK, you might be seen as a tax resident there.
segments.client_message: Ah, got it! So, would that mean if I decided to retire abroad, I might have to pay taxes in both places? That could get complicated, huh?
